name: Avery Lemley
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
At first glance, without protective measures seemed to be the better option to me. The faster we can all get over this virus, the better things will be. But thinking more about it I realized how selfish that was. You can see that taking these protective measures may make the virus last longer, but people are safer and will have better access to treatment. I've been ignorant enough to believe that neither me nor any of my loved ones will be effected by this virus. If someone I cared about got the virus and died, I would be extremely upset, but at least I would know we did all we could to protect them. The time frame of the virus passing has no importance to the lives being lost.

After reading "The Reveal" and "Stat Nuggets" for the graph, I realized it wasn't literal, but instead a way to show people how important it is to take these protective measures. The information shown was no real data because it didn't take into account any death rates, or age, or previous medical trouble, it was theoretically based on previous epidemics. You cant predict or prevent these events from happening, but you can take precautions and raise awareness for the level of threat that these pandemics cause.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info:
@Avery Lemley 
I didn't realize that this graph was theoretically based on previous academics. This point is interesting to me because  the coronavirus seems to last longer with less protective measures. For example the more people quarantine and practice social distancing the less the virus will spread, further preventing more cases. My point is that with protective measures in place the effect would be contrary to what the graph is saying. The time of the virus being spread would most likely be cut short.

name: Ryan Boaz
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
After reading the reveal, I learned that I was focusing on the wrong part of the graph. Instead of worrying about keeping the curve flat, I was creating hypothetical situations about what would happen if the healthcare system was exceeded. I also assumed that the graph was based off some data collected in the United States, while in reality it was all theoretical and only emphasizing the importance of "flattening the curve." I understand that mitigation is so important in reducing the number of cases, but I have concern for the state of the economy after the virus is contained. By flattening the curve, we will see less cases and less deaths, but will the global economic repercussions be worth those lives. Now, I'm not saying the economy is more important than people's lives, but a moral dilemma arises: save a thousand lives from the virus, or potentially lose millions from the aftermath. 

The reveal brought a perspective to my eyes about this graph. Instead of focusing on the y-axis, or the number of cases, I looked at the x-axis, or the time till the virus is gone. With proper mitigation and safety precautions taken, the curve can potentially stay below the healthcare capacity. This would be vital in our attempt to subdue the virus, even though the virus may exist longer. Ultimately, how we handle this virus, and the actions we take as a country, and as a globe, will be a defining part in history.

name: Kevin O’Malley
comment info:
Looking at my original thoughts and the "Reveal", I do see a few things contradictory to what I said. My original opinion was that the second curve was based on pure mathematics and calculations, but after reading the reveal, I now see that it is way more theoretical than that. First, the idea that the second curve will not exceed the healthcare system's ability is not certain. The graph is theoretical, based on other pandemics and rational thought, but not a certain curve that our country will get if we use the protective measures. However, I agree and understand the curve and know that it is achievable with the introduction of the protective measures.

Another thing is that I knowingly went off topic in my previous comment. I talked more about the time being used and how that would also affect the country. While I still believe this is important, I think that I should have focused more on the amount of infections, our health care systems ability, and how the introduction of the protective measures will help our country. Our country, like many others, has many cases, but we weren't the first ones. We should be looking at other countries to see what they are doing that works. China is a prime example and has used protective measures and lock downs to slow the curve. We now know it can be slowed and should do all we can to follow as they did to ensure the most American's safety.

name: Hayden Carroll

comment info: Before the reveal, I assumed that the graph was based off of a certain set of data, not necessarily just an info-graphic to persuade users to take precautionary measures. Another part of the graph that I payed more attention after the reveal was how the "with protective measures" graph reached the x axis much later than the "without protective measures" graph. I had to think about it, but it absolutely made since after I did. Taking precautionary measures to slow down the spread of the virus will increase the period of when a large number of people have it, it will just decrease how many people have it at a time. This is important so hospitals and other facilities maintain enough resources to treat those affected.

replies.name: A

name: Kevin O’Malley
comment info:
Looking at this graph, it is pretty self explanatory what is happening. With the introduction of protective measures the number of cases will not exceed what the healthcare system can handle, and while the process will be more slow, overall it is the best and safest way to protect our society during this crisis.
Looking at this, I notice that this is just an idea of what could happen and it isn't set in stone which curve our country is going to take. However, based on all of the steps our country has made to limit social interaction, I think that we are bound to take the second curve. As long as the country stays  abides by what law enforcement has said, our curve will not exceed healthcare's line, and we will suffer many less deaths because of that. 
I also have to wonder, is there anything else that our country can be doing to ensure we have that curve? We have shut down almost everything in the country, put many places into lock down, and stopped almost all social interactions in areas that have the most risk. Overall, I think our country has done almost flawlessly, but it also leads me to think what consequences might come from choosing this curve instead of the other one? There will be less death, but the economy will be suffering longer with everyone in lockdown. This could put us into a big recession and ruin our economy. It begs the question, is the suffering of the virus's effects worse than the effects we will receive from trying to stop this country altogether?

name: Lucy Fergusson
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
It never posted on the 27th so I'm posting it again: 
When I looked at the graph for the first time I thought I understood it completely. After I read the revel and stat nuggets article, looking back at the graph I understand it better. The revel states that the graph shows what could happen if people take protective measures such as social distancing and self-quarantine during the spread of this pandemic, Covid-19. And “does not show how many infected people there are, how many will recover, or how many will die” it is purely to show people why taking proactive measures does matter. I didn't know this when I first looked at the graph. I thought maybe it was a graph from another pandemic such as the spanish flu. The moderator's comments about the graph made me better understand exactly what it shows. I already knew that with proactive measures we can decrease the amount of cases but I didn't know that even with just “moderate interventions, the death rate can be cut in half”. While I was reading the article “Stat Nuggets” I came to understand that the mathematical model “Flattening the Curve Graph” does not predict whether interventions will 100% ensure that people who need medical care won't exceed the health care systems capacity. But the number of cases due to the pandemic won't exceed the number of cases the healthcare system can handle.

name: Yates Kirby
comment info:
Unlike many others, when I first saw the graph, the first thing that came to my mind  was "propaganda".  It reminds me of the graphs the USSR put out after Chernobyl, no real data, no real meaning, simply two scenarios designed to scare people into falling into line.  It really says nothing mathematical but comes off to most as mathematical which is scary to think.  
This graph is a theory, not based on any evidence of any kind yet is presented in a way that most see to be fact.  Whilst the theory may be correct, that diminishing the number of cases at the start would assist our health care system in treating those who are critically ill, it also has a negative side effect to it.  The longer this virus is around, spreading, the longer the world is stopped.  The longer people are imprisoned at home.  The longer students are out of school.  The longer factories are stopped.  The longer the virus has to mutate.  The longer people are living off the government.  The longer we lose our rights. 

While flattening the curve may mitigate the number of deaths, it may kill the economy even more.  It's a toss up, save a few hundred million globally from dying, or save a few billion from losing everything.  Save a few thousand while 30 million lose the right to work, 70 million lose the  right to leave their home, and the country falls into a depression that may take five to ten years to recover from.  Humanity or sustainability?  Few thousand dead or a few thousand businesses closed.

I felt the same way you did for awhile, until one of the teachers at my school passed away from the virus.  Then I realized how important it is that we stay at home, or we will just lose more people that we love.

name: Holly
comment info: “Protective measures” seems like a very unspecific variable in this situation. Social distancing is obviously inconvenient but it slows/prevents the exponential spread of the virus. If one person gives it to three people and then those three people pass it onto 3 people each, this is how exponential growth occurs. If that first person had never caught it and participated in social distancing, the chain would never have started.

	In response to some of the questions posed, first, I think that the length of the epidemic will increase with protective measures because instead of everyone getting infected at once, people will be slowly exposed. name: William Hudson
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info: This graph has been all over social media, the news, and other platforms so I was aware of the general meaning behind the graph. However, the extra discussion helped me learn more nuances about the graph that I discovered when I dug into the Star Nugget articles.  The one that interested me the most was The Exponential Power of Now.  On the surface, the graph makes you think about repercussions for different approaches by entire communities - either taking action or not. The article was impactful, because it points out the power of taking action quickly.  Delaying social distancing increases cases by 40%.  Said differently acting now, reduces cases by 40%.  This turns the negative of exponential growth into a positive because people can take action to stop it.

name: Brynn
comment info: After reading the reveal, I was surprised to find that it did not include any number of cases or death rates. The reveal was more about the impact that preventative measures can have on the disease replication rate and how spreading can be prevented. I also found it interesting to read about the different levels of isolation that a person can face. The reveal was a very good, concise rundown of what can be done to limit the negative effects of covid-19.

name: Sean Hession
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Before the reveal, I looked at the graph as a commendation. I thought the graph was a representation of how COVID-19 was already affecting the United States. However, after the reveal, I now realize that it is a theoretical mathematical model, created by specialists like Dr. Harris from the article. Looking back at the comments of others and the moderator, though, many people seemed to hold my prior thought: that the US was doing a very good job controlling the coronavirus. People thought we were already following the blue curve, when in fact it should be what we aspire to, not what we congratulate ourselves on achieving.
         Looking at the article, "flattening the curve" becomes seemingly even more important. If the peak number of cases can be kept under the healthcare system's capacity, the outbreak is much more manageable. Looking at graphs of each country's cases, however, it is evident that the US will need to do more in order to get on track to follow the blue curve. The early numbers of cases in the US are such that numbers may rise high enough to meet the red curve, which could be catastrophic. A better job must be done distributing testing kits, quarantining those infected, and continuing social distancing. Some seem to think the outbreak is slowing, that it is okay to slacken social distancing. This is untrue. It is important as ever to continue social distancing to slow the spread of the virus, follow the blue curve, and avoid chaos.

name: Juliette
comment info: The reveal described, in no uncertain terms, the level of influence we all have in terms of spreading the virus. We owe it to ourselves and to our communities to practice social distancing and self-isolation. The reveal provides statistical backing to this claim. Multiple simulations have shown that even small day to day changes can have a measurable effect on the spread of the virus. What was most striking to me about the reveal was the extent to which statistical analysis proves the effectiveness of intervention methods. By comparing the spread of the virus in different countries, with the explanatory variable being government mandated interventions, it is clear that countries with aggressive systems in place in order to fight the disease experience a far slower spread of the virus. After thinking about this model I find myself wondering what the distribution of coronavirus cases in America will look like at the end of the pandemic.

name: Margot
comment info:
Before the reveal, I knew that there was a large difference in death rates with or without protective measures, but I did not know that even with moderate precautions, death rate can be cut in half. Of course, these simulations/models are very sensitive to all kinds of variables. I wonder how we can stop or block these. variables... I still wonder how the decrease in the infection spread rate makes the epidemic last longer. If there were no protective measures followed, the epidemic would pass over in a quicker time span. Obviously, we know we still do not want that because it would exceed the healthcare system limit. But how does following protective measures almost double the timeline of the virus? The graph still makes it clear why it is important to follow protective measures ASAP like cancelling public gatherings and school. 
Also - I am very proud of my classmate Evan from Portsmouth, NH for being mentioned in a NYTimes reflection. Your headline was creative and deserved that honorable mention. Very good Evan!

name: Emma Bradley
comment info: Before reading the reveal, I expected to be informed about the exact number of  cases and other precise numbers from data collection on this graph. I found it very surprising that this graph was solely based off a simulation. I am glad that they are attempting to further educate citizens on this severe issue and stress the fact that protective measures need to be taken in order to end this virus. I think they brought up a great point when saying how we can do simple things like social distance and close schools to prevent further death and maximizing the health care system capacity.

name: Olivia (4B)
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info: After reading the reveal for this graph and the “Stat Nuggets”, I definitely understand the concept of a mathematical model much better. Before, I knew that the graph was not based on any data from the coronavirus, but I still misunderstood certain specifics behind the graph’s meaning. For one, I thought that the peak of the “with protective measures” curve meant that the model predicted that with interventions our health care system will not be overwhelmed by the number of patients in need of attention. With a stat nugget, I discovered that while the model does predict this circumstance to be less likely, it by no means ensures this outcome. Mathematical models such as this one are very helpful in making decisions on the steps to take in “flattening the curve” and other similar situations, but it’s crucial to understand that they are purely prediction based. There is no definite or one hundred percent certain prediction that can be made; these models simply show the most likely outcomes based on previous patterns and knowledge.

name: Dominique
comment info: I was shocked read that the death rate could be cut in half with proper safety precautions. Moreover, understanding the true meaning behind "flattening the curve" is crucial in the preservation of our nation's health. With misinformation spreading, it is necessary to be aware that anything can happen, regardless of the results of a simulation. The Stat Nuggets provides a potentially accurate representation of our future, but we should still be aware of confounding factors lurking throughout the pandemic.

name: Ryan P
comment info: The piece of information that interested me the most after seeing the reveal was that the model was purely theoretical. That model is based on no data at all, it is just to help explain easily what could happen in self-isolation. I thought that the Flatten the Curve graph took into account actual data, but now I realize that this would be almost impossible to model realistically.  It also interested me that this model was based on past worldwide epidemics. This begged the question, "what epidemics are the model based on," and "is that data really reliable." The only pandemics that were as worldwide as COVID-19 is today were the Spanish Flu and Sars. I wonder if it is valid to compare other epidemics that happened at various times in history to an epidemic happening in 2020.

name: Olivia
comment info: The follow up information further defines variables of the graph, including the degree of protective measures that would be applied  to achieve the lengthened curve of cases that falls within the limits of healthcare services. The Stat Nuggets solidified that the graph is strictly theoretical as it is a simulation, in the circumstances of COVID-19, it seems close to impossible to gather accurate data that is true to the situation regarding actual cases, deaths, and recoveries. For me, the 'reveal' of the graph was not surprising as no numbers or real statistics were provided given that it is a simulated model. I wonder what the true model would look like in comparison to the simulation if, ideally, there were a way to gather accurate data of the pandemic.

name: Evan C
comment info: The line stuck in my head from this article is "even with moderate interventions, the death rate can be cut in half." We keep hearing #FlattenTheCurve #FlattenTheCurve, but that line puts it explicitly: staying home will literally save lives. Even with moderate interventions, you can save old Nancy down the street as where living your life as normal may kill her. It is inevitable that misinformation will be spread about this virus, but being literate about "The Curve" as our society has dubbed it can help dispel that misinformation and save old Nancy down the street.

name: Bella
comment info: I expected that the reveal would tell us exact numbers and data and thought it was interesting that it was simply a simulation. The part explaining how if we take protective measures less people will get the virus at one time and therefore it will take longer for our country to fully recover makes a lot of sense. I think that the graph shows why flattening the curve is important and I hope that we have taken serious enough measures.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Bella Great observations! I hadn't thought of it this way, but now that I've seen this I agree that it is important to flatten the curve.

name: Mason Evans
comment info:
Now that I have seen the Stat Nuggets, everything has changed for me. Originally, I saw the graph as one not of prediction, but one of exact answers, and the Stat Nuggets immediately disprove that. The graph is just a prediction with no guaranteed answers and no concrete difference between the number of infected people based on interventions. Flattening the curve is obviously something that needs to happen to protect the world, but the data from the graph is not from an actual situation and instead from a prediction. 

Flattening the curve, whether it keeps us under the healthcare threshold or not, is still important because it gives the most people the highest chance of survival. Sure, the virus will occur for longer because it won't burn through patients as fast, but it will ensure that our healthcare systems are not completely overwhelmed with the number of patients. If we let everyone get infected, we would have to fight the disease without any hospital help and simply rely on our immune systems, which is very dangerous. 

Based on the simulation, it is definitely still necessary to practice social distancing and even possibly lead into forced quarantine. People think that "people under the age of 40 and above the age of 5" will be ok because of their developed immune systems, but my mother, who works in the medical field, says that the affects on all age groups is irreparable.

name: Uma Volety
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
I have always been big on statistics and facts, which is why I was excited for the statistical reveal of this graph. I thought that there would be more numbers, statistical tests, and, for lack of better words, more "factual" information in the reveal. This graph, however, wasn't based on scientific studies or mathematical projections, but rather observations and theoretical sense. That doesn't make the graph, or the message that it is showing, any less important.

I've been hearing about flattening the curve since Coronavirus was a thing people were making memes about on Instagram. My parents have explained the concept to me and made sure that I understood why it was so important for our community, country, and even the whole world. As it says in the article, "flattening the curve keeps society going". 

Something that caught my eye in the article was the transmission paragraph when discussing how to turn the red curve into the blue curve. The article stated that even though the transmission could be compared to that of seasonal flu, many people are already immune to seasonal flu through antibodies (your body's naturally acquired form of immunity) or vaccines. No one is immune to COVID-19. I think that it is important for people to understand the novelty of this virus and how easily we can peak the curve more than it needs to. If we can all follow social distancing orders from governors, the president, and the CDC, then together, we can flatten the curve and stop COVID-19.

name: Taryn Connolly
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info: After reading more into the articles, the reveal, and the moderators' comments,  I can now understand the article more. In my opinion, I was thinking that the graph would be super accurate to what would happen if all people started to take preventative measures, and it would basically be the same, but there are many more things in the real world to factor in, not making it as perfect. 
After reading the Reveal and Stat nuggets, I was left realizing that while even if we do take preventative measures, the number of cases still could be above that line, more than the healthcare system can handle. I also know that cases and death rates would also still be decreased by a great amount, which should be reason enough for everyone to be more aware of everyday things. For example, washing their hands or using hand sanitizer after touching gross surfaces and not touching their face after, like the man in the article. 
To sum up, I don’t see the graph too differently from how I saw it in my first comment, but I now realize how many factors go into this pandemic, with who is more likely to get it or to die, and I see that the real-life graph wouldn’t be as perfect.

name: Jacob Jarrett
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
When I first looked at this graph, I felt it was already apparent what I was reading. It says it right there in the red and blue. This is the curve with protective measures. This is the curve without. Then we look towards the axes and we see "# of Cases" over "Time".
 In other words, it's a mathematical model- a prediction, an assumption- of what might happen in 2 different pandemic scenarios. One where we're lenient. One where we're active.
 It was neat reading about the origins of this model, and I enjoyed getting to know a bit more about what it meant and who it came from, but it all feels so unnecessary to me. This graph is extremely thorough, quite frankly, and I really felt that no explanation was needed.
 The graph just screams: "stay at home so our healthcare system doesn't overflow with patients!"

name: Mia Kennedy
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Unlike I had predicted, the graph is not based on data but shows what the numbers would most likely be if proactive measures were taken. In this ‘reveal’ article, it tells us that the graph was made to show us why we need to take these proactive measures and stay safe. This article states that “The mathematical model behind this dynamic graph predicts that even with moderate interventions, the death rate can be cut in half,” which gives me hope. They also discuss the fact that there is a graph showing the number of new cases in countries with over fifty confirmed cases. Basically, we got this, but we really do need to take these proactive measures and practice social distancing. 
In the Stat Nuggets for “Why We Need To Keep The Curve Flat,” they tell us that “The Flattening the Curve graph is a theoretical mathematical model based on what scientists and staticians have observed from prior epidemics. The model predicts that, if there are proactive interventions, the number of cases in any time period will be less likely to exceed the health care capacity system.” This tells us that again, like I said, we need to take these proactive measures and take care of ourselves and others! This virus will be so much more contained and less intense if we just followed these precautions. Honestly, reading the article and viewing the moderators comments made me see the graph differently because I didn’t realise that the graph wasn’t based on data.

name: Sam McNamara
comment info: One of the first things that stood out to me when I read the reveal is that this graph was not created based on statistics; rather, it was created as an approximation of what preventative measures against the Coronavirus can do for us. I initially thought that this was a graph that mathematical model that had the x and y axes removed for the sake of allowing us to guess what the real numbers were. However, I now understand that this is more of a theoretical model based on past experiences than it is a statistical model. Another part of this article that caught my eye is how much variation there is to this model depending on many different factors, such as age distribution, fatality rate, and replication rate. Even with how much of our attention is dedicated to this virus right now, we have very little idea of what the overall death total will look like or a solid prediction of what this virus may do.

Overall, this will reduce the death toll. The peak is prodigious when social distancing is not accomplished, so it is important to flatten the curve.  In Stat Nuggets, the passage explains how this data was based on prior epidemics. I found that extremely intriguing. The mathematical model is created to predict the future characteristics of a real world problem in terms of both  qualitative and quantitative data.Does this model mirror the past epidemics, or where are there differences within the predictions?The model furthers the idea that safety is key.

name: Aidan O'Neill
comment info:
By implementing protective measures, I think the number of cases at any one time would decrease because it slows the rate of infection. This also explains why the epidemic lasts longer because everyone will be infected at a slower rate. 

Interventions that could be instituted to change the outcomes shown in the graph:

time since first case: reducing protective measures so that people are infected at a faster rate or vice versa.

number of cases: fail to quaratine those who are already infected and allow them to roam freely in order to increase cases, put in place even stricter policies to reduce.

health care capability: invest more money into the health care system to help the number of patients treated, divest money to do the opposite.

I think the easiest of these changes to implement would be to allow people to continue to roam around and do whatever they want causing infections to increase while the lenght of the epidemic decreases. The hardest to implement would be to put in place even stricter protective measures to reduce the infection rate as well as increase the time since first case.

name: Aidan O'Neill
comment info: All of the curves with the exception of the attempted quarantine curve were as symmetrical as the New York Times graph. The reason I think the quarantine graph is not symmetrical is because the quarantine essentially creates two separate graphs, one of initial infection, then a second outbreak after quarantine. Naturally, the first outbreak is small and is easily brought down. However, when the second outbreak occurs, it hits harder, producing a curve much larger than the previous one, hence why as a whole it is asymmetrical in nature. The amount of intervention I support would be high levels of social distancing, which calls for only 1 in 8 people traveling and greatly reducing the infection rate while greatly increasing the recovery rate.

name: Elliot Wells
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
After reading The Reveal, Stat Nuggets, and the original article, I think my original assumptions based on the theoretical mathematical model were partially wrong. I understood what the graph was saying, but I didn’t draw the right conclusion from it. The article explained that there would be a higher death rate and widespread panic if we didn’t take preventative measures, which I had sort of understood, but only when I read it did I realise just how bad that could be. People are already hoarding toilet paper, and I would hate to imagine what it would be like if people thought it was a given that they would get the virus.

When I first saw it, the graph seemed very incomplete, and after looking at Stat Nuggets, I can see why. It’s meant to be theoretical, so it says nothing about duration or the extent to which the virus will affect the population. It could be completely wrong, as well. No matter what preventative measures we take, we can’t say how well the healthcare system will be able to address the issue. Healthcare professionals could also get sick, or they might not have the right tools to prevent deaths or spreading of the virus. It’s not mentioned in the article, but the graph also doesn’t take into account the possibility of a second wave of the virus after the quarantine ends. All of this makes the graph just a little sketchy.

name: Gracelynn Whitaker
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
I probably haven’t been concerned enough about the virus. Beforehand, I understood that healthy people were transmitting the disease and that our healthcare systems were preparing to be overrun, but looking at the models from the Washington Post really helped me grasp the transfer of COVID-19. 
My original comment stands true to the information after the reveal- if we take protective measures, we can slow the spread of the disease. We must flatten the curve. But when I was writing the comment I didn’t understand how important this was. Looking at the Washington Post models, if we social distance, we will be able to control the virus and flatten the curve. We will be in it for the long haul because the spread of the disease will go much slower (and it will continue to spread), but we might just be able to scrape by without overrunning the healthcare system.
Of course, these models provide no guarantee that won’t happen anyway. But if we can prevent doctors from becoming ill themselves, if we can prevent doctors from having to choose which has to die, we must be willing to be uncomfortable in our social distancing, we must be willing to stop going places. Because even if you yourself aren’t sick, someone else you see might be, and then you might carry the disease to someone at risk. That’s why it’s important to eliminate the temptation to be out and socializing in public areas, why we should close public places, as the article says. We will have a chance to save more people.

I also stated that one curve will result in a large amount of infections per day but won't last very long and the other will result in fewer infections per day but will last longer. I think the best type of intervention is probably somewhere towards the safe side. We don't want this to last super long but we also don't want to overwhelm the healthcare system. I think we should try to keep our health care system busy but not overwork them so we can get through this as quickly as possible without overworking them.

It’s important that our health officials and staff do not feel overwhelmed during this time and that they have enough medical equipment to treat everybody; therefore, it is clear that protecting as many people as possible no matter the length of time, is the right decision that our country is making.

In order for us to flatten the curve effectively, we, as citizens, are the first line of defense and we need to start defending better. We hold the power to combat and stop this disease from spreading, so we need to use that power. I like the line that was highlighted in the article by Lilly, stating, “protect our healthcare system by protecting yourself.” Like the article mentions, canceling school and public gatherings, and preparing hospitals have helped us control the spread of this disease, and we should continue the practices suggested by health care officials.

name: Sadie Dunne
location: Hoggard High school in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
At first glance of this graph a few days ago, I noticed that everything researchers, scientists, doctors, and public officials were saying was true to a significant extent. Remaining at home and social distancing yourselves from as many people as possible will indefinitely lower the curve. With an open mindset but a more serious one as well, I now notice more about the healthcare system capacity not just across America, but across the world. The curve titled "Without Protective Measures" completely breaks the line for our healthcare system. When I look at this line, I see one that's not strong and bold, but rather already dotted. This makes me wonder if the graph is trying to make a point by showing people that the healthcare system can be broken. In fact, it will be broken if we don't take serious measures, everyone included, to stop the spread of this pandemic. 

A lot is going on in this graph. Some people may just see two simple opposing curves where one breaks through a line and one does not. But others, who really care and look closely, may see that the "With Protective Measures" curve almost touches the health care system capacity line. This tells us something of very high importance- doing everything we can to stay healthy, stay educated, and taking the most precautious measures may not even be enough in itself. But it's surely our only chance at preventing the number of cases from continuously growing exponentially. 

I would title this graph "A Break in the Curve."

name: Grace Robertson

(Part 2)
In my own state, the cases increase every day along the logistic model (as of this morning, we have 763 confirmed cases, but surely we all understand that not everyone is tested and for a case to be “confirmed” it has to be checked with the CDC in addition to the doctor/nurse who administered the test). Maybe this means the events we miss will continue to be cancelled and we’ll be working from home for a while, but if it saves lives and helps our hospitals, I think it’s definitely a price worth paying.

name: Harrison Carter
comment info:
When I initially looked at this graph last week, I understood it as the importance of following protective measures at the time of a pandemic.  I believed it showed how practicing social distancing and good hygiene can save the lives of others.  The graph encouraged me to stay away from large crowds and to wash my hands constantly.  Due to Covid-19 being in the United States for such a short period of time, I predicted that the graph was only based on mathematical predictions.  There has not been enough data gathered to prove the validity of the graph and that is why there are no numbers and statistical increments on the graph.  

The “Reveal”, published on the 26th of March, backed up my previous claims.  The graph is simply a mathematical model based on data from previous epidemics.  It should be used to gain qualitative and/or quantitative understanding and not be taken entirely literally by the public.  Scientists use these hypothetical graphs to keep the public informed and to encourage them to practice the suggested protective measures.  It represents the impact Covid-19 will have in America if we don’t follow protective measures versus if we do.  The graph shows how valuable interventions are when fighting a virus.  Interventions like drive-through testing, cancellation of public gatherings, school closings, and preparation of hospitals greatly slow the spread of Covid-19.  These precautions will decrease the infection rate and deaths across the nation.

name: Grace Robertson
comment info:
(Part 1)
We need protective measures to limit the cost of this virus. This was made even more clear to me after reading over The Reveal and Stat Nuggets. It can be really frustrating being separated from the people you love for so long, stuck in your house, but it’s worth it. The article predicts that even with moderate interventions, the death rate can be cut in half; imagine how many lives can be saved if we take more extreme measures! If we restrict interaction to the very minimum, we’re less likely to come into contact with infected people and/or items; the illness will be contained, or the spread will at least not be quite so rampant. And no matter how much interaction we have, it is vital that we be very meticulous with our hygiene. Hand-washing, while simple, goes a long way. A simple bleach solution to spray on door handles and gas pumps is also a great example of potentially life-saving cleanliness.

name: Shivani Patel
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info: The Flattening the Curve Graph is based on prior epidemics which makes it a theoretical mathematical model of the Coronavirus. The goal, of course, is to flatten the curve with the least possible deaths while, also, staying under the healthcare capacity line. The article provides a fairly simple solution to making sure that we reach our goal, and that is, social distancing. New York, or more specifically, New York City, is a fair representation of the red curve, and in order to mitigate it into the more reasonable blue curve, we need to take some precautionary measures. With social distancing, there will be less people packed in one place which will ultimately slow down the spread of the disease. There will not be so much as a surge of cases that overload hospitals, so we will be able to control and handle the virus much better which means less deaths. To explain the idea more clearly, the article compares it to a subway car during rush hour. The subway car is the hospital, and it can only take so many “patients” at a time, so the rest have to wait at the platform. By staggering work hours (practicing social distancing), the rush hour will be less of a rush since less people are in need of the subway car at one time, so people are more likely to be able to get on the car and have a comfortable ride.

name: Lucy Fergusson
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info: When I looked at the graph for the first time I thought I understood it completely. After I read the revel and stat nuggets article, looking back at the graph I understand it better. The revel states that the graph shows what could happen if people take protective measures such as social distancing and self-quarantine during the spread of this pandemic, covid-19. And “does not show how many infected people there are, how many will recover, or how many will die” it is purely to show people why taking proactive measures does matter. I didn't know this when I first looked at the graph. I thought maybe it was a graph from another pandemic such as the Spanish flu. The moderator's comments about the graph made me better understand exactly what it shows. I already knew that with proactive measures we can decrease the number of cases but I didn't know that even with just “moderate interventions, the death rate can be cut in half”. While I was reading the article “Stat Nuggets” I came to understand that the mathematical model “Flattening the Curve Graph” does not predict whether interventions will 100% ensure that people who need medical care won't exceed the health care systems capacity. But the number of cases due to the pandemic won't exceed the number of cases the healthcare system can handle.

name: Cooper Hyldahl
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
After reading the stat nuggets and "The Reveal", I am wondering why the virus is spreading so rapidly. The article says that the best thing we can do is to close schools, end public gatherings, and make tests more available but we have done that and the virus is still spreading rapidly. Schools across the country are shut down, many for the remainder of the year, and over one-fifth of Americans are under mandatory shelter in place orders. What more can we do to stop the virus?
Mathematically, the virus is still spreading at an exponential rate globally and in the US. When an exponential graph is converted to a logistic model, it typically looks like a straight line. If the line has a positive slope, it is still increasing at an exponential rate. In the US, we are still going up at a positive slope on the logistic model. We haven't even hit the inflection point yet where the virus begins to slow. This mathematical fact makes me question what is going to happen to the country. Are we all going to end up like New York? Are the worst case scenarios of 2/3 of the nation being infected going to play out? All of the data being thrown our way truly scares me and makes me question what we are doing wrong. 
The analogy of the subway in the article was very helpful for my understanding of the model. We as Americans need to listen to our leaders and stay home because if we do not, our "subway" is going to overflow and we will not have enough supplies for everyone.

name: Francine Wei
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
After reading the reveal, I realized that an important factor to flatten the curve is changing the mindset of people. The article about which countries have flattened the curve shows how countries like China and South Korea used strict interventions and regulations to slow down or prevent the spread of the virus. Although the graph shows how the curve could stay below healthcare capacity through protective measures, those measures need to be strict and followed by everyone or else the healthcare system will still be overwhelmed like it is now.

Through this theoretical graph based on past data from earlier epidemics, it shows the future of COVID-19 based on our decisions. Although some stores have implemented safety measures for their customers, people who don’t believe in the severity of this pandemic are still holding intimate gatherings of people with slides filled with germs. 

Social distancing itself will not necessarily flatten the curve in the theoretical graph. What is needed is the consciousness of society to be proactive and realize that the parties that they are having may not affect them, but it will be a factor in hindering the progress of healthcare workers and flattening the curve.

To those who want to stay home when they have to work or go to school and aren’t staying home when they are finally told to, please be mindful of all the other people who are working night and day to battle this virus. Stay home, eat some snacks, and binge on some new shows.

name: Carter Osborn
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
The Reveal and the Stat Nuggets actually confirmed my original response to this graph. Because there is no numerical data in the x or y-axis, the graph is clearly a representation of the world in general, and the effects of social distancing. The Reveal mentions that, "If there were no interventions now, like drive-through testing, cancellation of public gatherings, school closings, and preparation of hospitals, we would exceed our healthcare system’s ability to take care of those who are sick, which would increase the number of deaths. Interventions now will put the brakes on the spread of the infection, will decrease the infection rate, and decrease hospitalizations and deaths."
Only we can control and end the spread of this virus. Social distancing is a real thing, people! Nike has begun a campaign, and their slogan is, "If You Ever Dreamed Of Playing For Millions Around The World, Now Is Your Chance: Play inside, play for the world." This is exactly what we need to do in order to flatten the curve of coronavirus cases. Stay inside, no matter the cost.
The Stat Nuggets are not necessarily stat nuggets in a sense, because the graph is based entirely on what scientists and statisticians have found from previous epidemics. However, I have a feeling that their predictions are indeed correct. With more precautions, we will have fewer cases. It is quite honestly a basic human principle: The more careful you are, the less chance you have of getting hurt.
Stay inside!

name: Lilia
comment info:
The reveal clarified the purpose of the model to show what will happen if the population takes protective measures.   Instead of displaying numerical values, the model was published to encourage change in our current behaviors to prevent the escalation of calamity.  Implementing protective measures will delay the peak of the coronavirus outbreak.  As a result, the number of cases at a given time will decrease and the length of the epidemic will increase.  Although the duration will increase, a much greater proportion of patients with coronavirus will be able to get adequate care, reducing the number of deaths.  In other words, increasing the duration of the outbreak will ensure that all patients have access to medical care, and the hospitals are adequately equipped with professionals and materials.  

It was also intriguing to learn about how this theoretical mathematical model is developed.  When statisticians and scientists use observations from prior epidemics, I wonder how they choose which epidemics to compare the coronavirus pandemic to.  Furthermore, I wonder if this "Flatten the Curve" model, or a similar one, has been developed for past epidemics.

name: Mairead Benson
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
We need to slow down the rate of infection with the Coronavirus.  It is probably the most important thing to do right now.  Every day while watching the news with my parents, I hear the Governor of New York, Gov. Andrew Cuomo, begging the U.S. government and private investors to send more medical supplies to New York State, specifically to New York City.  They were not prepared for the COVID-19 outbreak and it hit them the hardest.  As of March 26, there have been 37, 258 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in New York State, and 385 of those people have died.  Doctors and hospitals are so overwhelmed that they are calling for retired doctors and senior medical school students to come and help them.  And because of that, large numbers of people are dying in NY State.  
In my county in North Carolina, there are only 4 confirmed cases of COVID-19, and no deaths so far.  Why?  Because people - for the most part - listened to Governor Cooper.  Practice social distancing, no gatherings of more than 10 people, schools are canceled until May 15, and other precautionary measures have been put into place.  Governor Cooper canceled schools in North Carolina almost a week before Governor Cuomo canceled schools in New York.  And because of that and the other precautions we are taking, we have 4 confirmed cases of the Coronavirus and no deaths.

name: Jessie
comment info:
Title: Flattening the Curve for a Society Conserved 

I am currently writing from the comfort of my bed at 1:06 pm on a Wednesday - a time typically reserved for test-taking at a forlorn desk or picking up lunch from the school cafeteria. Like me, many have faced alterations in day-to-day routines since the coronavirus outbreak. This is because social distancing measures decrease the rate at which COVID-19, what the CDC deems a global pandemic, proliferates, as reflected in the figure at right. 

The two curves shown depict the relative number of infected individuals with and without protective measures like community isolation. Not only does the overall number of cases decrease tremendously with protective measures, but the peak amount matches the carrying capacity of the health care system. In this way, significantly fewer people will be affected when we self-isolate, as shown in blue, and all of those who do become infected can be treated. In the instance that social distancing and other protective measures do not transpire, however, the avoidable illness will plague thousands more, and there will be a lack of resources to help all those who need aid. I wonder how health care providers will choose which people receive treatment and which do not should this be the case.

name: Simone Cronier
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
“Our Goal: Merge the Curves”

The graph shown is depicting two different bell curves. The red curve with a narrow standard deviation shows there was an influx in the number of those infected with Coronavirus earlier on. This large surge in people made it very hard for the healthcare system to take care of everyone because there wasn’t as much information on how to contain the virus yet when it first broke out in late December. There was a very high average number of people diagnosed with the Coronavirus in a short period of time when we didn’t take protective measures like washing our hands and social distancing ourselves which resulted in overcrowding at hospitals. Now that people know to social distance themselves, the blue curve with wide standard deviation shows that people are listening to the authorities and implementing protective measures to keep themselves safe and how this helped bring down overcrowding at healthcare facilities. 

What healthcare officials are trying to do is bring down the red curve in a way that doesn’t put the lives of those already infected at risk. We’re trying to gradually bring down the red curve to merge with the blue curve, not run around throwing doctors in every possible direction to strangle the disease out. This spreading out of doctors is exactly what causes overcrowding in hospitals which exceeds healthcare system capacity. The only thing I wonder is where we are on the graph.

name: Oscar
comment info:
How Covid-19 will spread over time with and without protective measures. 

        The red bell curve is the one representing what would occur in a situation in which no preventative measures are taken to reduce the spread. The graph shows a steep incline after the first case, at its peak, it begins to level out showing that the peak infection time is over, exceeding the healthcare capacity by a large margin. On the flip side of this, the pandemic runs its course and dies out much more quickly. Still, the hospitals have been overrun with cases and there will be many casualties to come.
         On the other hand, when certain precautions have been taken the course takes longer but does not result in as many casualties. I wonder though, if we are taking only some preventative measures it would be somewhere around the middle of the two, meaning the hospitals will still be overrun but with not as many casualties due to priorities of who would get help or not, correct? if so why do so many people still not worry about this highly infectious disease?
         About quarantine though, I think that it will help in more ways than one because people are staying home and practicing social distancing, fewer people are at risk. also since fewer people are traveling carbon emissions have most likely been cut by a large portion. I hope that this comment helps people understand the current situation that we are in. I personally found the graph worrying considering our situation at the time.

HI, @Oscar --

Really thoughtful noticings and wondering.  Just one point -- Though these graphs are bell-shaped, they are not what people call bell curves or statisticians call normal curves.  Bell curves are for histograms and have a number line x-axis.  This has  time on the x-axis and is a kind of a time series graph.  It's bell-shaped, but not a bell curve.  

How about a catchy headline which captures the main idea of the graph?

name: Skye Solomon

comment info:
This graph shows the importance of taking protective measures against the coronavirus, including social distancing. The first thing I noticed when I looked at it is the drastic difference between the number of cases with and without protective measures. Even doing the simplest things like self quarantining in our homes can make a huge difference on the impact this virus will have on us and the amount of deaths it will cause. 

When I first looked at this graph, I wondered why we would want to prolong this disease when we could just get it over with and everyone could go back to their normal lives. But after thinking about it, I realized it was more important to make sure that we save as many people as possible and don’t overwhelm our medical workers. Flattening the curve may not be the most convenient for most people, but it is better than the alternative where many people die because we did not have the resources to help everyone.  

I wonder how accurate this graph is, and if it’s still possible for us to flatten the curve that much. I don’t know what our healthcare system capacity is or how close we are to reaching it right now, but if we still have time it is important that we do all we can now before it’s too late.

I also am curious to see what the number is for the Healthcare system capacity line.

replies.name: S

replies.comment info: @Bella Steiner COVID-19 only has a 2% mortality rate, but that’s only if everyone who needs to can get to the hospital and have access to the supplies they need. If our hospitals are overwhelmed, then they won’t have the resources and medical staff available to save everyone. This is why social distancing is so important for flattening the curve, not so less people will be infected, but so that the number of cases stays below the healthcare system capacity line. The same number of people could end up contracting this disease either way, but by taking protective measures we are increasing the number of people who will survive.

comment info:
We Fear What We Can’t Control

What I first noticed was the shape of the graphs. Both graphs are basically bell curves, which is something I learned last year in math. The term means the highest point of the graph is the most likely thing that will occur, while the other two sides are equally proportioned. Therefore we are basing our fate off of one point, while the rest is out of our control.

Mainly this graph shows two realities. One predicts what will happen if no cautionary  measures are properly followed, while the other shows what would happen if we were to do the right thing.

Although I wonder what the right thing or answer truly is, because if we were to follow the first than it shows it would be over much sooner. While the “right thing” would carry on much longer, but stay within our health departments control. If we have control then it remains low risk, while if it’s out of control there is no telling other than the outline of the red graph.  So overall it’s a matter of control, much like anything else in the history of our world.

name: Gracelynn Whitaker

comment info:
We are starting to lack the ability to care for patients during the coronavirus. According to the graph, if we take protective measures to prevent the spread of the virus, our healthcare system should just be able to scrape by tending to people as is. But since preventive measures haven’t always been taken, our healthcare system is being overrun by cases, and they have to make the difficult decisions on whom to fight for and whom to give up on because they simply don’t have enough resources. As time wears on, though, I notice how the curve will drop and fall back into our ability to tend to these cases. If we take preventive measures, the spread will be slower, and the care will last longer, but doctors won’t have to choose which lives to save. 
I wonder how the US cases compare to the slopes on this graph, and if there is anything we can do this late in the game to reverse the slope of the cases that hospitals have coming in. It’s terrible to be in the position of a doctor and decide which of the suffocating patients needs most of your attention and to have to run the risk of being in one of their places every day by tending to them. 
My title for this graph would be Controlling Coronavirus: Why Our Healthcare System Needs Our Help.

@Gracelynn Whitaker  First off, I want to say thank you for bringing up strong points that actually hold factual evidence. All over social media, teenagers our age are treating this time, this time full of unknown possibilities and extreme fear, as though it's a vacation. I hope that some of those people read comments like yours and realize that this period that the whole world is going through is anything but a vacation. name: Grace Robertson
comment info:
Even though all of this coronavirus-induced chaos may possibly be over sooner if we just go about life as usual (without protective measures), it'd come at a high cost. Our healthcare system is not prepared to handle that many coronavirus cases in so short a period of time. We have neither the equipment, nurses/doctors, nor the beds. However, if we take protective measures such as social distancing, we won't be able to entirely stop the spread of illness, but we'll be able to slow it down enough so that our healthcare system won't be overwhelmed. Clearly, the graph shows that with protective measures, we'll be dealing with this virus for a longer period of time, but I believe that if we spread out the number of cases over more time, there will be fewer deaths and better care.

What I don’t know and wonder about is how this will affect our country and world in other ways, especially economically. I wonder if the economic consequences will be more/less severe if we spread out the number of cases, or if it doesn’t matter. This virus affects our world in so many ways I don’t expect, and I anxiously wonder how we’ll be affected in those (at least for me) unforeseen ways.

With all of these things in mind, I would name this graph The Cost of Not Social Distancing. That sounds kinda blunt and maybe even a little dramatic, but as we can tell from the 2 different curves of the graph, one much steeper than the other, that is what I have gathered from what’s going on in this graph.

name: Graceanna
comment info:
Title: "Saved by the Bell (Curve)" 

The graph shows the contrast between number of coronavirus cases without protective measures, and with protective measures, in relation to the level of preparedness of our healthcare system. Without protective measures (self-quarantine, basic hygiene, etc.) the curve is much higher than our healthcare system can handle; this implies hospitals are overpacked, not prepared to take care of that many cases, or lack of medical supplies. However when protective measures are taken and people abide by the "stay at home" rule, the curve flattens and it becomes within the healthcare systems capability. It is also interesting to see the point in time at which the "without protective measures becomes the "with protective measures." (the increase starts to decrease).

replies.comment info: @Graceanna I love this title! It is super clever and perfectly captures the main idea of the figure. I also like how you chose to analyze the point of intersection between the two curves. You had mentioned how the increase of the "with protective measures" curve begins to decrease at this point. However, I think the curve may start to have a negative second derivative even before the intersection. This is all the more telling of how beneficial protective measures are, as the number of cases begins to increase at a decreasing rate even before the alternative instance reaches this lower range of case amounts.

name: Grace Romano
comment info: This graph shows how protective measures against COVID-19 really flatten the curve. Without social distancing and sanitation, the virus would spread like wildfire, jumping from person to person at incredible rates. With protective measures, however, less people would get infected from this novel Coronavirus. The amount of cases would stay within the health system’s capacity, and countries like Italy would not be running out of respirators. I’ve been doing research into COVID-19 since it was still in Wuhan, and as I’ve seen, lack of protective measures are what caused this pandemic. The Chinese Propaganda Machine tried to keep it under wraps, instead of helping their people fight this new pathogen. It spread to other countries in Asia, and then to European countries. It is interesting to see how different handlings of the virus have caused different outcomes. South Korea pioneered the ‘drive through testing’ and gave updates on the virus every day, while Italy didn’t do enough until it was too late. Just recently, an Italian mayor said they will start deploying police to enforce the lockdown- with flamethrowers. This is because Italians don’t listen (trust me on this one, I’m Italian). The scary thing is, Americans don’t listen either. Florida beaches such as Clearwater were filled with young people who are unafraid. Hate to tell you, but here in the US, young people currently have higher rates of infection. If we don’t practice social distancing, we’ll end up like Italy.

Come back next week when we will have another graph that shows the effect of levels of intervention on transmission of coronavirus. Also, you can see the effect of different levels of protective measures by going to this animated simulation (https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/world/corona-simulator/).
It’s amazing!

name: Cooper Hyldahl
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
This graph shows the importance of social distancing. If we social distance, the amount of people that are infected with the virus at any given time will fall, reducing the demand for medical supplies and vital machinery like ventilators. When people do not socially distance, the infected expose many more people, infecting them and so on. The number of infections increases exponentially, overwhelming the healthcare system. The virus then burns itself out, but not before thousands would be dead from a lack of medical care resources. If social distancing is implemented, the infection rate will slow, making the virus take longer to burn itself out but decreasing the number of cases at any given time. 
The government can only do so much for us. Many complain that the government is not doing enough to help Americans and in some cases that is true. No one should be evicted because they can't go to work because of the virus. But, that being said, many things can be done ourselves to do our part in stopping the virus. The government cannot be blamed for everything. Do your part and stay at home.

replies.name: G
replies.comment info:
@Cooper Hyldahl
I agree, Cooper. I hate staying home all day, away from my friends and seemingly living in my computer screen, but I understand it's me doing my part to help slow the spread of COVID 19. The government is doing all it can and instead of blaming them for our corona-related problems, I think it'd be much wiser for us to just do our part by social distancing and making perfect hygiene a personal priority.

replies.name: S
replies.location: Hoggard High school in Wilmington, NC
replies.comment info:
@Cooper Hyldahl  I agree with you, the best and most efficient way to prevent any further cases of the virus is for people to stay home and social distance themselves from others. This really cannot be emphasized enough. The number of COVID-19 cases we have in the world right now is excessive. We need to make sure that this disease doesn't continue to grow exponentially, and every individual person must do their part. Health care workers and doctors are already putting in enough time and effort to take care of those infected, they certainly should not have to choose between who to treat and who to withhold treatment from.

 You're right, no one should be kicked out of their homes or loose the right to accessible healthcare or food simply because they've been laid off of their job or can't work right now. It doesn't matter who you are or where you come from in this situation, the whole world must support one another as we suffer through this time together.

name: Shivani Patel
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info: The first thing I see in this graph is the big red curve representing “Without Protective Measures” that shoots well past the healthcare capacity line. It peaks as the blue “With Protective Measures” curve is still on the rise, and it dies as the blue one finally peaks but stays under the capacity line. I wonder if it’s worth it to have less control on the Coronavirus (lay back on the protective measures such as social distancing by shutting down businesses and schools and limiting travel) and let it die out faster, or keep in control, under our health care capacity, and let it die slowly. There are pros and cons to both that are pretty well established by the graph. If we let it run its course, then we can get back to our normal lives much sooner, but that means that our healthcare system will not be able to manage the virus and the higher number of infected people as well, so more deaths are likely to occur. On the other hand, our economy will take a heavy blow due to the shut downs lasting a lot longer, but our healthcare system will be able to manage, so less people will die, and we would be a lot safer and in better hands if we were to get it since there are much less cases. Either way, there is much to think about, and not a lot of time to think. The number of cases are on the rise, the death toll is rising, hospitals are running out of room and supplies, and the stock market has taken quite a hit. I would headline this graph as “The Two Faced Coronavirus Debate.”

name: William Hudson
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Part I 
Choosing our Roller Coaster Ride - Which Curve We Achieve is a Life or Death Matter

While most people are impacted by social distancing and hygiene measures to flatten the pandemic curve, it is equally vital to focus on the capacity of our healthcare system. Healthcare system capacity is driven by number of hospital beds and materials needed to treat patients as well as the number of healthcare professionals available. It seems unclear where we are on this curve for the US, my particular state of North Carolina, or even for my local hospital, which only has about 700 beds for a population of 300,000 people.  

If we are early in the curve, do we still have time to act by increasing restrictions on every day life or by adjusting our healthcare system by adding new beds in hotels or dorms? Or, are we on an uncontrollable roller coaster that is climbing to a deadly peak of increasing cases with no chance to change course?  At some point, there will be a point of no return like Italy is experiencing.

name: Sean Hession
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Headline: Why We Need to Practice Social Distancing
     I notice that in the graph, it is predicted that the peak number of cases if protective measures like social distancing are not used is much higher than if protective measures are used. If protective measures are used, it is projected that even the peak number of cases will be below the healthcare system capacity. However, if protective measures are not used, the amount of cases will greatly surpass the healthcare system capacity. This graph seems very similar to what has already happened in some countries.
        In some countries, the prediction relayed by the graph has already taken place. For example, in Italy, protective measures were not used in the widespread manner they should have been used. As a result, hospitals have been overwhelmed. Medical supplies have run short, and heart-wrenching decisions like who will get a life-saving respirator have had to be made. This is the situation that people in the United States are trying to avoid through social distancing. It is predicted that by doing what the United States has done, by using social distancing, peak cases will never exceed the healthcare system's capacity. This has worked thus far, as the capacity of the healthcare system has not been exceeded yet. Even though capacity has not been exceeded, the outbreak is still extremely bad. This leads me to wonder how bad the pandemic would be in the US if protective measures were not put in place.

name: Sydney Pugh
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Looking at the graph, there are two bell curves plotted show what the number of cases of COVID-19 will look like over the timespan from when the first case appeared, to when it is predicted to die-off.  One bell curve shows just how many cases are predicted to appear during a given time without protective measures, while the other bell curve shows what that will look like with protective measures being implemented.  The line represents how many patients and cases the healthcare system is able to treat at any given time.  

It can be seen in the graph, that if no protective measures are taken against preventing the spread of COVID-19 the amount of time which COVID-19 will persist may be shorter, but there will be a much larger amount of cases during its peak, and with such an influx of cases at a given time, there won't be enough medical support to properly treat many of those cases, and leading to many more deaths.  

On the other hand, if protective measures are thoroughly being implemented, the spread of COVID-19 will still occur, but it will happen at a much slower and smaller rate.  Meaning it would persist for longer, but those cases will all be able to get the medical attention they need, and many more people would be able to survive.  By buckling down on taking protective measures can decrease many preventable deaths from COVID-19 due to the shortage of medical attention, and decrease the amount of people infected by COVID-19 at its peak.

name: Uma Volety
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Stay Home, Save a Life

I wonder how many people look at this and say "Why are we practicing social distancing? It's only hurting us." I can understand how that misconception is common, as it appears that taking protective measures elongates the lifetime of the virus, but if you look closer, the longer the virus is around, the more victims our healthcare system can treat.

Upon examination of this graph, it is evident that without protective measures, our healthcare system will be grossly overwhelmed. For teenagers, this virus isn't very lethal. However, just because it isn't lethal, doesn't mean that you won't need medical attention if you do contract it. The other day, one of my friends talked about catching Coronavirus just to "get it over with." As nice as this may sound for teens, it can be deadly for society. Even if COVID-19 doesn't kill you, just a little bit of fluid in your lungs can warrant hospitalization. If you, an unsympathetic teen, is taking up resources in a hospital, you are denying those services to someone who is at risk of dying from this virus.

So, stay home. Don't go out with your friends, to the grocery store, or expose yourself to anyone else unless you have to. I know, social distancing sucks, but you're doing it to protect the people and healthcare officials in your town. If this graph tells us anything, it isn't that social distancing is hurting us, but that it MUST happen if we want to overcome this virus with as little casualties as possible.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Uma Volety I like you how you take a strong stance in your answer! Can you relate your take to the results of the graph further?

Beshear has closed all non-life-sustaining businesses in Kentucky, how do you think that will affect the curve for Kentucky? name: Aaliyah Butler
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Stop Touching Me! Stop Touching Yourself! Stay At Home!
Yes, we know that the coronavirus is going around and that it is serious. We understand that people are scared for themselves and their loved ones, but that does not mean we leave our houses and show that we are panicking. All we are doing is putting ourselves and others at more risk to catch the virus and give it to the ones we love when we go back home. As you can see in the graph, without protective measures, the number of cases are going to exceed what the healthcare system can handle, which means that more people are going to die. With protective measures, even though it will last a little bit longer than without protective measures, it stays below what the healthcare system can handle, which means less casualties. I say we are somewhere in the middle of both estimated sets of data because although we are making sure we have the right equipment to fight off diseases, we are still going outside of our houses to do so, which means we are still touching things that others have touch and who knows if that person sneezed or coughed all over their hands before touching objects that others have to touch. I work at Harris Teeter so all I see is people, some with no protection on them, walking around touching things and putting them back, others have face masks and gloves on, smart. Simple solution and request, stop touching things, wash your hands, and stay inside if you have no valid reason to leave the house.

name: Ayush T
comment info:
This graph depicts the scary reality of the coronavirus; with or without protective measures, there is a high chance of being infected. The non-protective measure curve, however, has a percentage of people who do not fit in the healthcare system capacity. Once again, this statistic shows how bad the pandemic has gotten in terms of containment.
 Somewhere out there, a person with coronavirus symptoms may not receive the help they need, a harsh consequence for not taking adequate protective measures. For many people, not taking protective measures may be a matter of ignorance, however, some people may not have had a choice. A sizable percentage of the companies in America do not provide sick-leave pay, and in the midst of the pandemic, some people may not be able to lose income. As a result, these companies have created an unsafe workplace environment and have contributed to the overload of our healthcare system. 
Our society needs to come together and ensure that no working-class citizen feels as if they are being backed into a corner and forced to work.
