name: Olivia (4B)
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info: I noticed that while this graph is a model that was made prior to the epidemic, the pattern displayed with both the hypothetical scenarios seems to be pretty accurate based on what has played out with the virus and its transmission. I also noticed that the blue section labeled “with protective measures” manages to conveniently peak just below our labeled “healthcare system capacity”. I have no doubt that this model is accurate in showing how protective measures impact the quantity of cases, but I wonder how the highest point just so happens to be right below health care capacity. Of course, this is what we want to see, but I wonder if even with all of our protective measures in place we still might go over that dotted line. I don’t believe it would be as drastic as without our protective measures, but I still think it is more likely than some of us believe. I don’t want to be pessimistic, but I think people should be prepared for a potentially compromised health care system even if our efforts to distance are strong. I think a disease like COVID-19 is contagious enough to overcome our preventative measures even if they go surprisingly well. It’s important for the public to stay positive in a time like this, but I believe we have to be careful in not crossing the line of naivety and underestimating this disease. A possible title for this graph could be “A Goodbye to COVID-19 Is Up to You” or  “Flattening the Curve: You Make a Difference.”

name: Sofia Noonan
comment info:
My first thought when I heard news reporters say we need to practice social distancing was, "how ridiculous is this?" I was upset that school was cancelled, and I was upset how much this virus has changed millions of lives as well as my own. This graph chages my perspective by showing in actuality, how important social distancing really is.

   This graph represents how the number of COVID-19 cases suddenly spiraled and went back down without any protective measures, and it also shows the gradual growth and decline of cases. This leads me to wonder, in the long run, does it truly make a difference to take such big precautions? The graph shows the huge impact the virus had withought precautions, but it also shows how fast it stopped affecting people. Why not just let everyone contract the virus and live through it? 

   I realize that's a rather insensitive question, but it's one that I have heard many friends and family wonder about. Although I question the ways we are going about this pandemic, I do believe that right now, social distancing and self isolation is the best possible way to get through it. Society has never dealt with a virus like this in the 21st century. It is a new thing that we are all trying to navigate. I find it interesting how society has been able to come together and fight against this virus.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
Thank you for your post and your honesty, @Sofia. You mentioned wondering “does it truly make a difference to take such big precautions”, so my question to you is, “Other than range of the graph and slope, what is the biggest difference between the two graphs?” Specifically, looking at the dashed line, what does that change about how the virus affects our society?

Do you have a catchy headline you would suggest for this graph? I’d love to hear it.

replies.name: O
replies.location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
replies.comment info:
@Sofia Noonan I had a similar reaction when I first heard about the seemingly extreme degree we were being told to take social distancing to. I was a bit annoyed that my daily life was going to be far from normal in the upcoming weeks. However, I did pretty quickly come to terms with the physical isolation we have been following, and I understand why it is so important to follow through with these preventative measures. 

I also saw the much shorter timespan that this model portrays in which people have the disease when protective measures aren’t taken, and I wondered why this was the case. Regardless of what we may have at risk, I don’t think that allowing everybody to contract the virus and “get it over with” as some people may see it is an option. If we look at the graph closer, we can see that the dotted line representing our health system’s capacity has been overcome vastly with no social distancing and other practices in place. There are still many people in this world that cannot contract this virus with any assurance that they will recover or even survive. Our health system is not in a place that can take that many patients in need of critical care. Risking that many people’s lives so that we can try to rid society of this virus sooner is not worth it in my opinion. I don’t think it is our place to put our own desires to resume our normal schedules over the lives of others.

name: Emma McLaughlin
comment info:
I notice how much flatter the curve gets when protective measures are used against this virus. It is also interesting to see the health care capacity line. I have heard on the news many times about countries like China and Italy having to turn away patients because of the number of people that have the virus. This is really concerning, but I think it is important to hear, the same thing could happen in our country if we are not careful. Now is the time to use protective measures to flatten the curve and make sure our healthcare system is able to provide for everyone that needs to be provided for.

I also find it interesting and surprising that with protective measures the virus will actually last longer than if no protective measures are taken. I find this really odd, I would think that protective measures would both lower the number of cases and the amount of time it is around for. I am very interested to see why this is when the reveal for the graph comes out.

 I wonder if people will participate in social distancing after seeing this. Although social distancing is not fun it really is necessary in lowering the amount of people getting the virus. I also wonder what other protective measures we can use to flatten the curve, the only one that I have consistently heard is social distancing but if there are other ways to slow the spread I would be interested in hearing them. 

I think a good headliner would be, ‘We can flatten the curve.’

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @Emma McLaughlin I believe the reason for the virus lasting longer when protective measures are taken is that If everyone was to contract the virus at one time, it would run its 2-3 week course and then be out of most peoples' systems. However, if the curve is flattened and elongated, certain people will be contracting the virus at later times than others, which means that healthcare workers can treat one wave of people and then treat the next wave of people without being overwhelmed. Imagine that there are four groups of people and that each group gets the virus one at a time. The hospital will be able to treat the group that is initially sick, ensure that they are all healthy, and then be prepared to treat the next group that gets sick. This would take roughly four times as long as compared to everyone getting sick and rushing to the hospital at once, which explains why the curve for preventative measures is longer.

name: Ryan Boaz
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
By looking at the graph, I notice there are two curves being studied, if you may. One curve looks at the growth of the virus without taking protective measures, and the other with taking protective measures. It seems from the data that the cases will fall back to zero faster without taking protective measures, but the healthcare system capacity will be exceeded. By using protective measures, it will take longer for the cases to fall to zero, but we will not exceed the healthcare capacity.

It’s important to understand that this data is all theoretical. Whoever compiled it can’t measure how the number of cases will change when the healthcare capacity is exceeded. The data seems to suggest there won’t be any changes to the curve after the capacity is exceeded. I wonder with the almost exponential growth of the virus, in addition to the healthcare capacity being exceeded, what that would be like on any scale. The data suggests that eventually the cases will go back down, but I truly wonder, would they? If we have no ability to contain the virus, who is to say the number of cases won’t stop going up? I fear that our healthcare system does not have the ability to handle such a vast number of cases, and if it does collapse, we would be in a crisis that the world has never seen before. The scientific community unanimously agrees that the priority has to be containment. Not doing so could be deadly. A fitting title could be: “Healthcare System Capacity Exceeded. Is it Worth it?”

name: Sadie Dunne
location: Hoggard High school in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
The number one goal right now should be to flatten the curve- to lower the amount of cases of people with the Coronavirus. And as this graph and research proves, the number one method for doing so is to practice social distancing. At first glance at the graph shown, I see that if we don't, as a whole society, stay home and socially distance ourselves from others, the number of cases will only continue to rise and hospitals will run out of the needed room and tools to treat people. Every human being must be more aware than ever now that their decisions really do affect others in a life or death manner. 

I applaud the countless healthcare workers out there risking their lives in hospitals, and as the graph shows, we can do our part to help them by staying home so that they don't have to worry about running out of treatment options and beds for sick people. There are many other ways to stay in contact and remain connected with people who you care about virtually. That being said, I don't think distancing ourselves from other people should be referred to as social distancing in every case. Rather, it could just be called distancing. 

Without protective measures, the graph proves that the amount of people diagnosed with COVID-19 will keep rising significantly. In order to stop that, each individual must do their part to stay healthy and safe. This means washing your hands, sanitizing objects that you use frequently, and keeping your distance from people to flatten the curve.

name: paige  biebrich

I noticed that without protective measures it goes way over the number of people that the health care system can take care within a short time. With protective measures about the same amount of people get infected but throughout a longer time span, which would make it easier on health care systems. name: Keira McWilliams
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington NC
comment info:
Serve America and Flatten the Curve
     The first thing I noticed was how taking preventive measures will make the pandemic last a longer period of time, therefore my immediate thought was “Why would we want to make it longer?” But when I studied the graph a little more, I noticed the dashed line, showing the capacity that hospitals can care for. People who get critically sick will need immediate care in the hospital and since COVID-19 is a respiratory illness, they will need ventilators, which are in limited supply in all hospitals. 
    Are we taking enough preventative measures to efficiently flatten the curve and have room for all who need care in hospitals? Where I live in Wilmington, North Carolina, I would like to say yes, we are taking a lot of preventative measures. Schools and most workplaces were shut down before we had any confirmed cases and all get-togethers of over 10 people were banned by the governor, Roy Cooper. On the other hand, places like New York City and Seattle are already flooded with cases, so I wonder if their hospitals are overflowing with cases yet. In situations where hospitals overflow, I painfully wonder how officials choose who does and doesn’t get the ventilator needed to save their life. I wouldn’t wish for my worst enemy to be a part of that situation, no matter their role.

I notice that without protective measures, the number of cases of a disease will rise much quicker, reach a much higher maximum, but then decrease quicker. name: Jessica G.
comment info:
1.) Based in the Protective Measures Graph, I noticed that with said protective measures, the number of cases remains below the healthcare system's capacity with a smaller curve. These protective measures most likely consist of practicing social distancing and washing your hands frequently. It is shown in the graph that practicing these methods will result in higher amounts of recovered, healthy patients. Without these measures, the curve is significantly larger, exceeding the healthcare system's capacity. A consequence of this will be more deaths of sick patients due to less medical supplies and overworked staff. In order to maintain steady and high percentages of recovered patients, the curve must remain below the healthcare capacity. 

2.) I wonder does every single person in the country have to follow this in order to see the "protective measures" results? Or what exactly is the health care capacity, does it differ around the country?

3.) "Why Does It Matter If I Stay Home Or Go Out If I'm Not Sick?" or "How Washing Your Hands Can Help Nurses and Doctors Nationwide."

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Jessica G. --

Great noticings and wonderings, but I ask you – Where “is (it) shown in the graph that practicing these methods will result in higher amounts of recovered, healthy patients?”  What is the variable on the y-axis?  What does this show? 
You ask if “does every single person in the country have to follow this in order to see the "protective measures" results?”  Come back next week when we will have another graph that shows the effect of levels of intervention on transmission of coronavirus.  Also, you can see the effect of different levels of protective measures by going to this animated simulation (https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/world/corona-simulator/).  It’s amazing!

name: Moderator
comment info:
Welcome to our moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  With coronavirus spreading to all 50 states and at least 170 countries, we offer this graph which shows how “flattening the curve” could reduce the number of infected people and the number of deaths by reducing the number of cases at any one time in our healthcare system.

What is “flattening the curve?”  What curve?  Why do we want to flatten it?  What do you notice and wonder about the effect of protective measures on the spread of the coronavirus?  Please recognize that this graph shows a model and not data.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph. 

We encourage students to respond to other students.  We expect teachers to respond to their students as well other students from around the world.

Before Friday, we will reveal the article that included this graph and much more.

I wonder what kinds of protective measures are displayed in this graph because there are many different levels of protection (living normally, avid hand-washing, social distancing, or full-on quarantine are a few examples), and what the slopes would look like for other protection methods. For example, if this is the slope with social distancing looks like, I wonder what the slope for full isolation of everybody would look like. I am also curious to know if this is a graph about what has happened in a specific place already or if this is a prediction of what will happen in the future in a specific place based on evidence of what has happened already in other places. A headline I have come up with based on this graph is “Respect the Capacity, Use Protection!”

name: Kristen
comment info:
One thing I noticed is that when protective measures are taken, there are fewer cases of coronavirus--about half of the cases as there would be if there were no protective measures. With protective measures, the cases are more spread out, allowing the healthcare system to be able to handle everyone who has the virus. Without protective measures, many people get the virus at once, and the healthcare system is unable to handle so many cases.

I'm wondering why the healthcare system capacity line hasn't changed over time, as more people are affected by the virus I feel that the healthcare capacity line would go down. I can also understand how the line would go up, if more hospitals are built or more medical staff are hired, but I'm wondering why it stayed the same over time.

A headline that could describe this graph is, "Why Protective Measures Are So Important" or "Our Healthcare System Can Only Handle So Much," because the graph displays how, even if taking protective measures, the healthcare system can only hold so many people.

HI, @Nikan Hodjat --

Oops!  The source that is listed is somewhat misleading.  The New York Times attributes the graph as "adapted from the CDC."  From the article, we know it is not from CDC data.  The graph is just a model --what we may expect with some kind of protective measures.  We really don't know if there will be more or less cases with protective measures, but we do know something about the new cases per day and the length of the epidemic. 

For sure we "Can't Stop the Spread but Can Slow it Down."

replies.comment info:
HI, @Cheyanne --
This model was designed by epidemiologists long before the coronavirus.  It is a model and is not based on data.  We really don’t know how the number of cases will compare between without and with protective measures. And, we don't know if "it will increase just as fast that it decreases."  You can read about what other countries have done and how this has flattened their curve in the New York Times article “Which Country Has Flattened the Curve for the Coronavirus?”  Do you think the number of infections will decrease at the same rate as they increased?

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Abby I think the protective measures are worth it, even if the same total number of people have gotten infected by the end of the epidemic. Plus, the peak in infections would be later, so doctors/researchers would have more time to figure out what the best treatments are, get the supplies they need, etc.

When we don't flatten the curve, the slope stays high but the length of the curve is much shorter. I wonder why we think that it will die out so quickly without flattening the curve. Why wouldn't it plateau for a while above the Healthcare System line? I wonder if it is going to have to sweep through almost everything before it can get any better. 
"Slow and Steady Wins the Race: Flatten the Curve and Win in the End" would be a good title. While it seems like ending it early (as seen in the "without protective measures" curve) is more ideal, taking a little longer while flattening the curve is actually more beneficial because it keeps our health and safety as the priority.

replies.name: B
replies.comment info: @Annalie Malone I think that you made some very interesting points. At first glance, it does seem that the route of no protective measures may be the way to go, which doesn't seem logical. I wonder how statistitions found that the virus would go away so quickly.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Annalie Malone I completely agree with you about questioning why the virus would vanish so quickly. I also wondered why the graph without safety precautions wouldn't plateau but just peak and drop.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Annalie Malone I like the question that you asked, "Why wouldn't it plateau for a while above the Healthcare system line?" I did not think of that at first, but defintely am curious now that I have read your comment. If it spreads so quickly, how do they know that the rate of spread will also decline just as quickly? I feel like the number of cases would stay at that higher point for a longer period of time.

name: Ella Krygowski
comment info:
At first glance, I noticed that the number of cases with protective measures is already almost at hospital capacity. Also, the peak of cases with protective measures is right in the middle of the graph, the peak of the number of cases without protective measures is right at the beginning, so that means it will get very bad very fast. After looking at this graph, I believe that protective measures are very important and they need to be taken in order for the healthcare system to treat the coronavirus in a timely manner. 
I am wondering, after seeing how much trouble Italy is in, is the graph without protective measures based on Italy’s situation? It seems like Italy got very bad very fast, due to the percentage of older people in their population and the fact that parts of Italy are still developing and probably many other factors. 
In the graph, the main headline that is going around is to “flatten the curve”, that is because the main idea of this graph is to continue taking protective measures such as self-quarantine in order to keep the number of cases of coronavirus under the hospital's maximum capacity. If that doesn’t happen, many more people will get sick all around the same amount of time, which would flood the hospitals leading to a lack of resources and possibly many more deaths or major cases. My catchy headline would be “don’t make a mountain out of a molehill”

name: Shelby
comment info:
I notice that both curves have the same area, but different distributions. It is because of the protective measures that the distribution is different; this difference is critical to health care system capacity. With a wider distribution, the probability of the health care system to care for all the cases goes up significantly. 
I wonder what a curve that represents less preventative and protective measures would look like. I also wonder what a curve without major measures (like social distancing) might look like in comparison to these two curves. Additionally, I wonder what one of these curves would show about the distribution of cases over time. 
Headline: Distributing COVID-19: Protective Measures Lengthen the Distribution Cases Over Time

replies.name: B
replies.comment info: @Shelby You make some excellent points. I think it is important to note that the curves have similar areas (number of cases) and without the variable of health care capacity you would lean towards the curve that takes less time. You make great points about how quickly the first curve would go bad and what a strain it would have on the world or area it is in.

HI, @Ravi --

Great noticings and wonderings.  
This model was designed by epidemiologists long before the coronavirus.  It is a model and is not based on data.  We really don’t know how the number of cases will compare between without and with protective measures, but there is something else we know about new cases and how this relates to our healthcare capacity.  You alluded to this in your response.  It has to do with mortality.  Take another look and share with us what you notice.

Also, please return on Friday morning, when we will share the link to the article that includes this graph plus other resources and graphs.
